DOCNAME: CASE OF BUNKATE v. THE NETHERLANDS
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - claim dismissed
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant is a GPE citizen born in DATE . He lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested in The Hague on suspicion of having committed forgery . He was placed in detention on remand until DATE , on which date ORG ( PERSON ) ordered his release on the ground of a shortage of cells then existing in the GPE .

CARDINAL . The applicant was tried by ORG ( Arrondissementsrechtbank ) of GPE on DATE . On DATE that court sentenced him to DATE imprisonment on CARDINAL counts of forgery . Both ORG and the applicant filed an appeal DATE . The applicant was allowed to remain at liberty pending the appeal .

CARDINAL . DATE after the judgment of ORG , on DATE , the applicant travelled to GPE where he stayed for DATE . While there he had a death certificate in his own name issued by the competent NORP authorities ; this document was dated DATE . The applicant ’s death was registered in GPE on DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant returned to the GPE on DATE . On DATE his mother applied to ORG of GPE for a court order to delete the entry of his death from the register . On DATE such a court order was given and the said entry was deleted on DATE .

CARDINAL . The appeal against the judgment of ORG of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) was heard by ORG ( Gerechtshof ) of GPE on DATE in the presence of the applicant . On CARDINAL DATE ORG found the applicant guilty of only CARDINAL count of forgery and acquitted him of the other ; nevertheless , it increased the sentence to DATE and DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant introduced an appeal on points of law to ORG ( PERSON ) on DATE , within the time - limit of DATE prescribed by GPE law , by means of a statement made at the registry of ORG . The registry of ORG transmitted the case file to the registry of ORG , which received it on DATE . The hearing of ORG was set for CARDINAL DATE .

The applicant ’s counsel proposed CARDINAL grounds of appeal . The first argued that since at the time of the hearing of ORG the registration of the applicant ’s death had not yet been deleted , the applicant was not then officially alive and the prosecution should therefore have been held inadmissible . The second was a complaint about violation of Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) of the LAW , in that , firstly , the transmission of the case file by the registry of ORG to ORG had taken excessively long and , secondly , the acts for which the applicant was still being prosecuted had been committed DATE before . Applicant ’s counsel claimed to have inquired often as to the date on which the hearing was to take place .

CARDINAL . In accordance with the advisory opinion filed on DATE by the Procurator - General ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal by judgment of CARDINAL DATE . It held , firstly , that the registration of the applicant ’s death did not preclude ORG from allowing the prosecution in view of the applicant ’s presence at the hearing and , secondly , that the lapse of time between the filing of the appeal on points of law and the hearing of ORG was undesirably long but not unreasonably so for the purpose of Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) . ORG further observed , inter alia , that although the applicant ’s counsel had inquired after the date of the hearing , she had not asked for that date to be brought forward .
CARDINAL . The applicant served his sentence from DATE until CARDINAL DATE when he was provisionally released .

CARDINAL . For a survey of the relevant domestic law and practice , reference is made to the judgment in the case of PERSON v. the GPE of DATE , Series A no . PERSON , pp . CARDINAL , paras . CARDINAL - CARDINAL .
